Important initiatives include the creation of a unified national power grid, the Deen Dayal Upadhyaya Gram Jyoti Yojana (DDUGJY) for rural electrification, and the SAUBHAGYA scheme aimed at universal household electrification. This has led to reduction in energy shortages from 4.2% (Fiscal 2014) to 0.1% (Fiscal 2025) and increased per capita electricity consumption from 1,395 kWh in Fiscal 2024 from 957 kWh in Fiscal 2014.

Even though manufacturing IIP declined in Fiscal 2020 to 129.6 and to 117.2 in Fiscal 2021 owing to the pandemic, it recovered to 131.0 in Fiscal 2022 on the back of easing of Covid-19 related restrictions, government stimulus measures, rising consumer demand and efforts to revitalise the manufacturing sector. Consequently, in Fiscal 2025, manufacturing IIP stood at 152.5.
## Industry sector accounts for approximately 31% of the total GVA in the Indian economy

Industry sector, which include Mining & Quarrying, Manufacturing, Electricity, Gas, Water Supply & Other Utility Services, Construction (Agriculture, forestry and fishing) and has retained its share of approximately 31% in Fiscal 2014 and Fiscal 2025.

Under the industry sector, Electricity, Gas, Water Supply & Other utility services GVA grew at a CAGR of 6.7% over Fiscal 2014 to Fiscal 2025 from ₹ 2 trillion in Fiscal 2014 to ₹ 4.1 trillion in Fiscal 2025 which is faster than the industry sector GVA growth of 5.8% over the same period.

The services sector, including Trade, Hotels, Transport, Communication & Services related to Broadcasting, Financial, Real Estate & Professional Services and Public Administration, Defence & Other Services registered a CAGR of 6.7% between Fiscal 2014 to Fiscal 2025 and continues to be a significant contributor to India's growth.

During this period, the sector contribution to GVA expanded from 51% in Fiscal 2014 to 55% in Fiscal 2025, underscoring its growing significance. In absolute terms, the service sector GVA stood at ₹ 94.5 trillion in Fiscal 2025 compared to ₹ 46.3 trillion in Fiscal 2014. This growth of services was driven by the significant domestic demand, rapid urbanization, expansion of e-commerce platforms generated heightened requirements for logistics, digital related services are important factors which have determined the domestic demand of services.
Share of agricultural economy, which includes Agriculture, Livestock, Forestry & Fishing, declined from 18% in Fiscal 2014 to 14% in Fiscal 2025.
